title: Arc Raiders Patch Notes Include Venator Nerf And A Duck Surprise
description: Embark Studios has released the patch notes for the latest Arc Raiders update, which details map adjustments, a nerf for the powerful Venator, and ammo changes. It also includes a welcomed surprise for duck collectors. The most notable change in this Arc Raiders update is the nerf to the game's powerful Venator pistol. The developer says it was aware that the fully upgraded Venator was over-performing and "capable of outgunning full squads using close-range weapons." The gun's nerf includes a reduction to the fire rate gained from upgrades, and it also receives an increase in weight. The developer says the weapon's weight was not previously in line with the other pistols in the game, so the weight was increased from 2 to 5. Another major nerf in the update affects the game's powerful Deadline mine. Players have been taking down the game's largest Arc enemies with the Deadline mines, and the developer seems to think it's been too easy to utilize, as the update makes it harder to obtain the mines. The buy value of the Deadline has been increased from 8,100 to 15,000 Coins, the crafting materials needed have also increased, and traders will now carry less stock of the mine. title: On The Day Of Your Job Interview, Do This
description: You have to get into the right mental state for a job interview. You know when your best job interview is going to happen? When you had a flat tire, or you couldn‚Äôt get a cab at the airport the night before. When you‚Äôre physically exhausted and wrung out, you‚Äôre more present in the interview. You don‚Äôt care as much. You aren‚Äôt pent up and nervous and mewly. The thing to remember before your job interview is that you‚Äôre going to do beautifully. You‚Äôre going to meet a new person ‚Äî what‚Äôs the big deal about that? There‚Äôs nothing to it. If they don‚Äôt want to hire you, God bless them. You don‚Äôt need them. You are perfect in yourself. When you get that and believe it, your job interviews will get a lot easier. Oh for God‚Äôs sake Liz, did you ever have to pay a mortgage? Did you ever have a car payment past due? Yes my darling, I understand that fear. I‚Äôm telling you that approaching the interview with the attitude ‚ÄúOh God, let me get this job!‚Äù can only hurt you. You want the job? Then you have to go in there and make it clear that you‚Äôll take the job if it‚Äôs a fit for you and you‚Äôll walk away from it if it isn‚Äôt. If you radiate the energy ‚ÄúPlease hire me, I beg you!‚Äù only a terribly fearful manager will hire you. The manager who will hire you in that state is someone who wants his or her new employee to be grateful for the job even if comes with emotional abuse threaded through it. That kind of manager can‚Äôt help you grow your flame ‚Äî he or she can only squash it. You have to believe in yourself before anyone else will. For thousands of years our species has valued courage. We talk about it incessantly. Courage is treating every job interview the same way whether the rent money is in the bank or not. You send out energy waves. Do you doubt it? Think of pheromones. There are confidence-mones, too. Dogs smell fear, and people are no different. When you go into a job interview ready to grovel and beg and roll over and play fetch, you‚Äôre toast. You have no credibility then. Your goal on a job interview is not to please anyone. Your job is to bring yourself to the meeting, completely. Only the people who get you, deserve you. The night before your job interview, lay out your clothes down to the pocket square if you‚Äôre bringing one. I mean your exact shoes, socks, underwear, shirt, tie, dress or whatever you‚Äôre wearing. If you‚Äôre wearing pantyhose to the interview, get them out. Try them on. Don‚Äôt take any chances. You don‚Äôt need one extra thing to think about on the interview day. Make a test drive or bus or train ride before the interview. Don‚Äôt take a chance that the address on the building is obscured by scaffolding or there‚Äôs a detour on the way. Go to the building and make sure you know where the entrance is. Check on the parking situation. Get all that logistical stuff out of the way. On the night before, make a list of questions. You‚Äôve got brilliant interview questions prepared, right? You must. Research the employer up and down on their own website and LinkedIn. Think about the hiring manager‚Äôs pain. Why is he or she filling this job? It‚Äôs not because it‚Äôs fun to hire people. Few people would say that it is. It‚Äôs nerve-wracking. They‚Äôre hiring someone because there are important things that can‚Äôt happen in the business until this person comes on board and gets things moving. That could be you! In the morning, go to work if you‚Äôve got a lunchtime or after-work interview. Otherwise, meditate and exercise. Listen to music. Clear everything out of your mind. You can do a little of this even at work if you get a quiet moment. Listen to your favorite song on your headphones. Here are 100 of my favorites to choose from. Get out your padfolio with a notepad and pen inside it. Write your questions on the notepad. Tuck several of your job search business cards and a few extra copies of your Human-Voiced Resume into the padfolio, and if you‚Äôre printing driving directions, do that now. If you can possibly exercise in some way before the interview, do it! Better to be exhausted than overly tight. Loosen up. Run up and down the stairs a few times if nothing else. My daughter is a 21-year-old operatic mezzo and I tell her to do ten minutes of brisk exercise before every audition. Jumping jacks are perfect, because you can do those in a small space. Wear yourself out. That‚Äôs the best way to quiet your anxious brain and relax so you can be in the moment in your interview. The common and awful habit of a job-seeker in an interview is to anticipate the interviewer‚Äôs every question and try to compose perfect Teacher‚Äôs Pet answers while the interviewer is still talking. In case you forgot, it‚Äôs extremely obvious when your conversation partner has mentally departed the room. Your perfect answer ‚Äî if there could ever be such a thing ‚Äî is not what the interviewer is looking for. The real you in the chair is a thousand times more important. Managers forget job candidates all the time.ROB: So Liz, you sent me this form to evaluate Janice Allen as a possible lab tech. LIZ: Yes. What did you think of Janice for your job opening? ROB: Honestly‚Ä¶ LIZ: Yes? ROB: Which one was she again? LIZ: Sort of auburn hair.. ROB: What‚Äôs auburn again? LIZ: Kind of a brownish-red. Chestnut.ROB: Not really a hair-color guy. LIZ: She has Cairn terriers ‚Äî like Toto in ‚ÄúThe Wizard of Oz.‚Äù ROB: Didn‚Äôt see it. LIZ: WHAT!? I‚Äôm speechless. ROB: For reals. LIZ: Did you see ‚ÄúMary Poppins?‚Äù ROB: That one I saw. LIZ: So Janice ‚Äî she worked at Motorola.ROB: Half the people we interview worked at Motorola. LIZ: Geez. She was a lab tech there. She worked on base station diagnostics. ROB: Nothing. Not even a ripple. LIZ: Here, let me show you her LinkedIn profile. ROB: Wow! Even with the profile, I‚Äôm not getting a reading. LIZ: And I brought her into your office. It was a busy day. This scene plays out in offices around the world, every day. Your hiring manager is busy and distracted. Then, they fall into the script and it‚Äôs a rote conversation. You have to change that energy. You‚Äôre not going to do that by answering the interviewer‚Äôs questions like a Good Little Sheepie interview. You have to step outside that frame completely. That means telling the truth in a job interview, rather than trying to give the interviewer the answer you think s/he‚Äôs looking for. It means spinning the table to ask questions yourself rather than sitting quietly like a person getting a citizenship exam, just waiting for the next question.Be real in the interview, thank the interviewer for his or her time, get up, and go home. Stop and get yourself a nice gelato on the way. You deserve it! Now the interview is over. Exercise or meditate some more. You are amazing. Everything that you said and did at the interview was exactly perfect. It was what was supposed to happen today. Don‚Äôt beat yourself up or second-guess your conversation, but do capture your notes and ideas about the interview before you go to bed. Call your wisest bestie and run down the interview with him or her, leaving out no details. Our friends are great at asking questions that need to be asked and making astute observations. The interview today gave you great learning. You won‚Äôt even know how much learning you got from it for months or years. It‚Äôs not important what the next step is or whether you continue in this hiring pipeline or not. You did your best. If you got ideas for your next interview, fantastic! You are growing new muscles. You are getting stronger all the time!

title: What Every Job-Seeker Needs To Know About Headhunters
description: Before you decide ‚ÄúI need to meet a headhunter who‚Äôll find me a new job‚Äù you need to understand how the third-party search business works. Employers pay third-party recruiters, sometimes called search consultants or headhunters, when they don‚Äôt think they can fill a job opening on their own. Sometimes they try to fill the position on their own and they can‚Äôt find anyone they want to hire, so they get their search partners involved. It is important to remember that recruiters work for their clients, the way all consultants do. They don‚Äôt work for the job candidates they collaborate with, although job candidates are naturally a critical piece of the puzzle for search consultants. Still, the employer pays the bills. This is why job-seekers are often disappointed when recruiters they meet aren‚Äôt always thrilled to give the job-seekers tons of free career coaching. It‚Äôs not that recruiters are stingy with their advice, or uncaring. It‚Äôs just that there are lots of job-seekers to help, and recruiters don‚Äôt get paid when they aren‚Äôt placing people into new jobs. Some recruiters are difficult, of course. Some of them are terse and some are mean. It‚Äôs that way in any profession. I‚Äôm an HR person. Do you think I‚Äôm going to sit here and try to tell you that every HR person is a warm, compassionate and wise evangelist for employees? Attorneys get slammed as rapacious sharks, used-car salespeople get tagged as hucksters. Every field and career path has great people in it, and other people who struggle to show their human qualities. It will always be that way. Still, people judge recruiters unfairly, because to make it as a recruiter you have to have a lot more than a phone number and a stream of jive. You have to understand what a client is telling you they need when they can‚Äôt articulate it themselves. You have to deal with client needs that can change dramatically overnight ‚Äî even in the middle of a search! ‚Äî and candidates who flake out, who tell you they‚Äôre excited about the job and then don‚Äôt show up for the interview, or who tell you at the last minute before the job offer comes ‚ÄúI think I might start my own business, instead.‚ÄùThere are two ways to be a third-party recruiter. You can work by yourself or in a firm with other people doing contingency search. If you‚Äôre a contingency recruiter, you don‚Äôt get paid unless your candidate accepts the job offer. You get a commission when that happens, equivalent to about 25% of the new hire‚Äôs first year cash compensation. What does it mean to only get paid when your candidate takes the offer? It means you may be competing with a bunch of other recruiters who also have candidates applying for the same job. It means staying on top of the hiring manager without irritating the manager so badly that s/he stops returning your calls ‚Äî even if you were promised feedback on a candidate by last Friday afternoon, and it‚Äôs now four days later. There is a lot of finesse in recruiting. The other way to recruit is to work for a retained search firm, or become a retained search consultant and work solo. Retained search people are hired by the employer to fill certain positions, often high-level jobs that pay upwards of USD $10oK per year in salary. When you‚Äôre hired to conduct a retained search, you‚Äôre hired ‚Äî you‚Äôre not competing with any other recruiters or search firms at that point. You still have to hustle to bring in candidates the employer will love. When one of those candidates is hired, the search assignment is completed. When we occasionally conduct searches for our clients at Human Workplace, this is the kind of recruiting we do. When you get a call at work or at home from a recruiter about a job opportunity, your excitement may impel you to say ‚ÄúSure! I‚Äôll send my resume right now! Where should I send it?‚Äù That‚Äôs not a good idea. The recruiter could be anybody. S/he could work for a top-notch firm or be a highly credible independent recruiter, or s/he could be a slimetastic wannabe who misuses your resume and damages your brand.Let‚Äôs say the headhunter who calls you is in the latter category. Let‚Äôs call our fictional recruiter Lola. Lola calls you at your desk one day when you‚Äôre working. She says, ‚ÄúWow! I‚Äôm glad I got you. I have a fantastic opportunity at Angry Chocolates, and you‚Äôre perfect for it!‚Äù You get all excited. You fire off a resume to Lola, and the next thing you know, Lola sends the resume to the HR VP at Angry Chocolates and says ‚ÄúYou should interview my candidate, who is perfect for your position!‚Äù The only problem is that Lola started her search business last week when she got sick of her job as the front-desk receptionist at a nail salon across town. God bless Lola‚Äôs pluck ‚Äî a pain-in-the-neck mani/pedi customer demanded that Lola go outside in the freezing rain and hail the customer a cab, to save the customer from having it to it herself. Lola told the customer where to go in her cab when she found one, and walked off the job. Lola decided to become a search consultant because the barriers to entry in that field are nonexistent. Anybody can become a recruiter, which is one of the things that artificially tarnishes the third-party recruiting community‚Äôs brand through no fault of their own. Lola already had a phone. She uses her gmail account to recruit from, and she‚Äôs in business. Geez! thinks Lola. That was easy. Now I need to get a search assignment, but wait! I have no experience and no credibility as a headhunter. I know! I‚Äôll find some job ads, and send the HR people behind those jobs ads really good candidate resumes. Where will I get the resumes? I‚Äôll call unsuspecting working people at their desks and tell them I already have the search assignment ‚Äî yeah! That‚Äôs the ticket. Then I‚Äôll get great resumes, send them to the client and maybe I‚Äôll actually get the search assignment for real. No one knows who Lola is. She‚Äôs never headhunted before, or networked, but her nails look amazing. She starts calling candidates. Not one of the eager candidates asks Lola ‚ÄúHow long have you been in search?‚Äù or ‚ÄúHow many people did you place into Angry Chocolates last year?‚Äù They should have asked those questions! Now Lola has ten resumes and she‚Äôs lobbing new resumes into Angry Chocolates all the time. The HR VP gets annoyed at all the unsolicited email she‚Äôs getting from Lola. ‚ÄúSome of these resumes look okay,‚Äù says the HR VP to the manager of the hiring department, ‚Äúbut who is this Lola? She has no track record, I‚Äôve never heard of her and I can‚Äôt even find a LinkedIn profile.‚Äù‚ÄúToo bad for those candidates,‚Äù says the hiring manager. The candidates never had a clue that their association with Lola was tanking their chances at an interview. If a legit recruiter calls them a week later, gets their resume and sends it into Angry Chocolates, the second recruiter may be told ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt interview that candidate, qualified as s/he seems to be. We already received that resume last week from Lola Somebody-or-Other.‚Äù The second recruiter may be able to place you into the job and get paid a commission if the employer is willing to go out on a limb with Lola and say ‚ÄúWe are not going to pay your commission because we had no relationship with you, and no agreement in place, when you sent us that resume before.‚Äù That being said, a lot of employers wouldn‚Äôt take that chance. They‚Äôd pass on you because they‚Äôd be squeamish about getting in the middle of a two-recruiter time-stamp dispute. Don‚Äôt give your resume to strangers, no matter who they say they know! Ask a lot of questions. Anybody who tells you ‚ÄúI have to have your resume tonight!‚Äù is full of baloney. Remember the old workstation-poster, usually photocopied at a crooked angle on the page, passed around from hand to hand? It said ‚ÄúA lack of planning on your part does not constitute an emergency on my part.‚Äù A recruiter in your corner is a blessing and a huge career asset, if your search partner is credible and wise. Lots of recruiters are. Accept no substitutes!

title: SIHH 2015: Introducing the Exceptional A. Lange & Sohne Saxonia Automatik
description: It‚Äôs January and every watch geek knows what that means. Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie, more commonly referred to as SIHH, has arrived! Amongst the exhibitors at this grandiose affair are Cartier, Piaget, Vacheron Constantin, A. Lange & Sohne, and a plethora of other Richemont brands and independent watchmaking houses. When it comes to ultra-luxury watches, I tend to prefer the simpler designs, such as the new Saxonia Automatik by A. Lange & Sohne. Just the thought of a 38.5 millimeter dress watch, for quite some time, I considered gauche. But since seeing Lange‚Äôs reinvented Saxonia Automatik, not only has my outlook on relatively large timepieces changed, but I‚Äôd be down to wear this watch any day. Its brilliant pink gold case is home to the splendid manufacture calibre L086.1 self-winding movement. As Lange‚Äôs 50th in-house caliber, this movement marks a milestone in the company‚Äôs great history as Germany‚Äôs foremost watch manufacture. I must add, never have I witnessed a finer finishing on any other automatic movement, and Lange‚Äôs creative use of German Silver is definitely something to laud. As expected, a power reserve of 72 hours and many components‚Äì209, to be exact. What I admire most about this piece is the elegant, simplistic solid silver dial. Oversized would be an understatement, but surely the dial is nothing flashy. If there was a perfectly-balanced dress watch, one that you can wear (almost) anywhere, the A. Lange & Sohne Saxonia Automatik would be it. For further information, please visit www.alange-soehne.com. title: Winemakers At The Vatican: Politics, Publicity, And The Influence Of Pope Francis
description: ROME ‚Äì Early yesterday morning, on a bus parked outside the gold-tipped fence of the Hotel Cavaliere, a cadre of Italian sommeliers made their preparations. They adjusted their uniforms, white button-down shirts contrasting with black pants, jacket, and apron. They tucked in here and tied up there, straightening ties, smoothing fabric, adjusting the chains and tastevin cups around their necks. There was a charge of excited energy in the air, as the sommeliers were joined on the bus by some of the Italian wine world‚Äôs most recognizable faces, from winemakers to management to journalists. At the appointed time, two more bus loads just like this one ‚Äì carrying about 150 people in all ‚Äì made their way to Vatican City, winding through the streets of Rome as dawn broke and the sun rose over the city. Wine as Religious Metaphor The delegation was on its way to an audience with Pope Francis, Jorge Mario Bergoglio, to represent Italian wine. The Pope‚Äôs family roots in the Piedmont wine region, before his grandparents immigrated to Argentina, are well-documented. He also uses wine as a metaphor in his teachings. On one occasion, for example, he compared the heart to a fine wine, saying that ‚Äúa heart that isn‚Äôt luminous is like bad wine: with time it spoils and becomes vinegar.‚Äù On another occasion he said that the elderly are like a ‚Äúfine vintage wine‚Äù with the ‚Äúpower to give us this noble inheritance.‚Äù So it was logical for the Italian wine delegation, initiated and organized by Franco Ricci of the Fondazione Italiana Sommelier as well as the Italian wine guide Bibenda, to request an audience with the Pope. General audiences, which take place in Paul VI Hall on most Wednesday mornings throughout the year, include representatives from religious and business organizations around the world. Marco Caprai, from the Arnaldo Caprai winery in Umbria, was one of the winemakers in yesterday‚Äôs delegation; this was his third papal audience, and for an earlier visit he was part of a group representing agricultural interests. How Can the Pope Help the Wine Industry? The idea of winemakers visiting the Vatican may have been logical and in keeping with the tradition of the General audiences. Yet, for me, it was a curious initiative as well. I wondered what, exactly, the group thinks that the Pope can do for Italian wine? Why did they come, and what did they hope would come from the event? These were the questions I asked throughout the morning yesterday, to different members of the group as we made our way from the Hotel Cavaliere to the bus to the Paul VI Hall. Their answers reflected a range of opinions. These three bottles of wine, made from Sangiovese, Syrah, and Merlot grapes, were part of a gift from the FONDAZIONE to the Pope on the occasion of the group‚Äôs visit to the Vatican yesterday. Photo Credit: Cathy Huyghe For some, it wasn‚Äôt at all about asking the Pope to do anything. It was about honoring the office of the Pope and this Pope in particular. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to separate the business of wine from the religion here,‚Äù said Angelo Gaja from Barbaresco, as we joined the stream of people walking to the entrance of Paul VI Hall. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to pay respect to this Pope,‚Äù he said, clearly enjoying his first papal audience, as well as the opportunity to see so many colleagues gathered together at once. Others pointed to the importance of a cohesive Italian wine industry at this particular moment in time. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs important for us to be united,‚Äù said Nadia Zenato of the Zenato and Sansonina estates near Verona. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to recognize the producers and our passion for the territory and our families.‚Äù Others mentioned the opportunity for this time away from the work of the industry. ‚ÄúWe are all together because of the same passion,‚Äù said Carlo Guerrieri Gonzaga of Tenuta San Leonardo in Trentino. ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs nice to have a moment where we are not thinking only of the wine. The important thing is to have a moment where all the world of wine is hearing the message of this Pope.‚Äù Still others saw it as a missed opportunity. ‚ÄúIt would have been a good idea to speak between ourselves, in a guided way, about the meaning of wine at this moment in the world,‚Äù said Florence-based journalist and sommelier Andrea Gori. ‚ÄúIt was a good occasion wasted, because it‚Äôs not easy to bring all of these people together.‚Äù And still others saw it simply as a PR event or, put another way, as an opportunity to bring attention to Italian wine and specifically to the culture of wine in Italy. That was the motivation of Franco Ricci, who requested the audience on behalf of the Fondazione Italiana Sommelier. If the Pope Pays Attention, Everyone Pays Attention The common thread of the responses from the winemakers and sommeliers was their recognizing the relationship between Italian wine and the position or endorsement of the Vatican in Italian life. If Papa Francesco pays attention, everyone pays attention.Attention, according to Ricci, is exactly what the Italian wine industry needs, in the form of marketing and communication about wine, particularly at a time when domestic consumption is decreasing and essential knowledge and appreciation of wine is lacking, especially among younger generations. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not easy to communicate the quality of Italian wine because it‚Äôs not easy to communicate about the land and the producers,‚Äù Ricci said. ‚ÄúThere are maybe 10 million Italians who know wine. There are 51 million who never will.‚Äù At the most basic level, the first steps need to happen within the government, he said. Even Italian school children can be taught to taste, starting with things like milk and olive oil. ‚ÄúThis could be a good start, to lay the foundation of wine culture in this country,‚Äù said Paola Simonetti, Bibenda wine editor. Petitioning for the help of government support is one path forward. Another path leads back to this Pope. Giovanni Mantovani, CEO of Veronafiere, said that he has been talking with Vatican representatives about organizing a smaller, more direct meeting with the Pope and representatives of Italian wine. Mantovani hopes that such a meeting can take place later this year. Cathy Huyghe writes about the business and politics of the wine industry. Find her online at cathyhuyghe.com and on Twitter @cathyhuyghe.

title: Three Things Every Job-Hunter Has To Prove
description: Sometimes when I listen to job-seekers talk about their resumes and their job-search approaches, I think they believe that a machine will be hiring them, rather than a person. The front of end of the typical corporate or institutional hiring process is automated. You know how I feel about those talent-repelling Applicant Tracking Systems if you read my columns. Still, that‚Äôs just the front of the process. The rest of the hiring pipeline is staffed by humans. Humans don‚Äôt hire people just because those people have the formal qualifications listed in the job ad. Humans hire other people because they believe in their guts ‚Äî the most important part of the body when it comes to making hiring decisions ‚Äî that a particular job-seeker knows what they‚Äôre up against and can jump in to help them sort it out. Job-seekers shoot themselves in the foot by forgetting why managers hire people in the first place. They hire people because they have to. Nobody ever hired a staff member just to spend money, or just to fill up an office that had some empty space in it. They hire people when that‚Äôs the best answer to a problem they‚Äôre experiencing. Maybe Sally retired last August, and Sally‚Äôs manager decided to hold off on replacing Sally. The manager tried to make it through without anyone in Sally‚Äôs position to see whether he could save money. It was an experiment worth trying, but it failed. It turns out that Sally‚Äôs job is essential to the department. As soon as Sally retired, everything started to fall apart. So now the manager is back out on the talent market. He‚Äôs placed a job ad and is waiting for responses from job-seekers. What is the manager looking for? He listed a bunch of job requirements in the job ad. He listed a bunch of essential job qualifications that he pulled out of ‚Äî well, he made them up on the spot. How much does Sally‚Äôs ex-manager really care about the ‚Äòessential job qualifications‚Äô he listed in the job ad? He doesn‚Äôt care that much about any of them ‚Äî he just needed some qualifications so that Robin, his HR person, would be able to screen resumes into a big pile of ‚Äúno thanks‚Äù replies and a smaller pile of folks to interview.See how bureaucracy works? The process itself rules the day and the people who might make amazing new team members have to bow to the process. We call that The Tail Wagging the Dog. It‚Äôs very foolish, but very popular! The stack of incoming resumes will be screened in or out based on the qualifications listed in the job ad. After that, no one will talk about the formal requirements of the job anymore. When the manager starts conducting interviews, he‚Äôll be looking for something more important than three years of this or a certification in that. He‚Äôll be looking for the answer to his burning question ‚ÄúWho can come in here and fix what‚Äôs broken?‚Äù Much more important than decidedly non-essential and often random requirements in the job ad are these three criteria: Does the job applicant understand what the job is? Can he or she read between the lines in the job ad, research the employer and through that research and his or her exposure to the working world, form an opinion about what the job might entail and how one might thrive in it? To use Human Workplace language, does the job-seeker understand the Business Pain this new person is being hired to alleviate? Secondly, does the job-seeker have stories to share ‚Äì stories that demonstrate the job-seeker‚Äôs understanding of the problem(s) he or she is being hired to solve? Your stories are far more powerful than your job titles, statistics and years of experience. Can you explain how you‚Äôll make a contribution in your new job, without waiting for a hiring manager to ask you ‚ÄúWhy should we hire you?‚Äù Lastly, does the job-seeker have the confidence to see him- or herself as a person with choices ‚Äî a person who doesn‚Äôt have to grovel and beg for a job, and wouldn‚Äôt do that even if someone wanted him or her to? Managers hire people who have choices. No one wants to hire the most grovelly job-seeker in the bunch, the one who‚Äôs willing to crawl over multiple piles of broken glass to get a job. Just because a manager asks hard questions in a job interview or challenges the job-seeker on his or her knowledge doesn‚Äôt mean that the manager doesn‚Äôt like the applicant. The manager may be asking hard questions because s/he‚Äôs seriously thinking about hiring you. They want to know if you‚Äôre up for the challenge. Often we think that the purpose of a job interview is to mewl and beg for a job, but no one respects a person who doesn‚Äôt respect himself. If you know you can do the job, then you‚Äôll be ready to ask tough questions about Business Pain and bring your whole self to a job interview. Despite what you may think, Sheepie Job Seekers who tell managers ‚ÄúI can be anything you want me to be!‚Äù don‚Äôt get hired first. They get hired last, if at all. When you have a problem ‚Äî a dented fender or a leaky pipe, for instance ‚Äî who do you call to fix it? Do you call the person who says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a plumber and I need work! I‚Äôll do anything you want! You name the price!‚Äù or a person you know can do the job well, either because you‚Äôve used that plumber before or because of his or her great reputation? When you have a problem, you hire the person you trust to get the job done. It‚Äôs the same in the talent marketplace. Managers hire people they trust to solve their problems ‚Äî like the problem where Sally retired and it turned out that the company couldn‚Äôt run without her. That manager isn‚Äôt trying to hire the person who has no self-esteem, and who makes it clear that s/he‚Äôs willing to do anything, be anyone and work for peanuts. The manager will hire the person who knows what he or she brings and can prove it.We always have the choice to accept a job offer or reject it. Even if the rent is due, we have a choice. The only way you‚Äôll grow your muscles as a job-seeker and as a working person is to use them, even when it‚Äôs scary, out on the edge. The faster you learn to walk away from the wrong opportunities, the faster the right ones will come in. In the meantime, ask yourself: Can I read between the lines in this job ad to see the pain my possible next boss is up against? Can I show through my Dragon-Slaying Stories that I‚Äôve solved this type of pain before, even if it wasn‚Äôt in my job title? and Am I ready to walk away from this opportunity if these folks don‚Äôt get me?

title: Real Estate Entrepreneur Joins Ranks Of Chinese Billionaires
description: A more than 75% gain in the past year in the share price of real estate industry entrepreneur Chen Jinsong‚Äôs Shenzhen Worldunion Properties has turned him into China‚Äôs newest billionaire. Chen, 51, with his wife Tong Jie holds 47% of Worldunion. The stake was worth 6.7 billion yuan, or $1.1 billion at yesterday‚Äôs closing price of 18.92 yuan. Tong isn‚Äôt involved in the business. China has been one of the world‚Äôs fastest-growing sources of new billionaires in the past decade. The 2014 Forbes China Rich List published last October had a record 242 billionaires, second only to the United States. The list was led by China e-commerce leader Alibaba Group‚Äôs Jack Ma. Worldunion said this week it expects net profit for last year to increase by up to 30% from $51 million in 2013, in part owing to acquisitions. The company announced plans last year to sell a 10% stake to U.S.-listed online real estate information provider SouFun Holdings for $120 million in a private placement that hasn‚Äôt been completed. SouFun‚Äôs shares have dropped nearly two-thirds in the past year on rough competition for advertising. Chen, Worldunion‚Äôs chairman, ranked No. 342 on the 2014 Forbes China Rich List with wealth of $760 million. Worldunion listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2009. ‚ÄìWith Maggie Chen‚Äì Follow me on Twitter @rflannerychina

title: Escaping JFK Arrest, London's Mayor Boris Johnson Pays IRS &nbsp;
description: Say it ain‚Äôt so, Boris? Tax protesters everywhere were hoping that the hopping-mad London Mayor and accidental dual U.K.-U.S. citizen Boris Johnson would stick to his guns and refuse to pay the IRS. The political tax brouhaha started when the New York born brit (who left America at age 5) said he couldn‚Äôt be taxable by the IRS as he gave up U.S. citizenship. Then it turned out he hadn‚Äôt, as the BBC confirmed, despite his threats to renounce in a column for the Spectator. Then there was outrage over American‚Äôs unique but expansive worldwide tax regime. The Mayor politely gave the IRS the finger, saying it was ‚Äòoutrageous‚Äô for the IRS to tax people all over the world for an accident of birth. Meantime, FATCA‚Äîthe Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act‚Äîis causing panic around the world. Banks and nations everywhere are ratting out Americans to the IRS. No account anywhere is safe from the IRS‚Äô prying eyes and FBAR penalties. (Image credit: Andrew Parsons) Up until now, the tousled blond mayor refused to pay the IRS, which must have felt good. But there was more than idle talk that he could face arrest on his next US. visit! So he paid his ‚Äúabsolutely outrageous‚Äù U.S. tax bill, escaping an embarrassing incident when he next visits America. U.S. law says all citizens, including dual citizens, must pay tax on worldwide income. And U.S. rules often trump others. U.K. tax law excluded Mr. Johnson‚Äôs London house, which he sold in 2009 for a reported ¬£1.2 million. But in the U.S., there‚Äôs no such luck. Rather than quietly paying the IRS, in an NPR interview, Mr. Johnson called it ‚Äòoutrageous‚Äô to tax U.S. citizens on their global income. Mr. Johnson noted that tax rates in the U.K. are higher than in the U.S. Still, the house sale was tax exempt in the U.K., so Mayor Boris can‚Äôt claim a credit for his U.K. taxes to the IRS. TO be fair, there was a tit for tat tax problem too. The Mayor has lambasted the U.S. Embassy in London for failing to pay London‚Äôs congestion tax. The Embassy says it is a tax and diplomats are immune! When President Obama was in the U.K. in 2011, Johnson reportedly asked him for a ¬£5 million cheque for unpaid congestion charges but the U.S. Ambassador intervened before President Obama could answer. By last year, the amount the U.S. Embassy owed more than ¬£7 million. The prospect of being hauled in by tax inspectors when Mr. Johnson touches down in Boston, New York or Washington in February must have changed his mind. Mr. Johnson has previously said he might renounce his U.S. citizenship. Yet most renunciations involve certifying that you are compliant with the IRS for the last 5 years. Renouncing isn‚Äôt easy and wouldn‚Äôt solve his tax bill. Apart from proving five years of U.S. tax compliance, you may have to pay an exit tax. Expats and disgruntled American taxpayers were happy that Mr. Johnson was calling attention to fairness. Many hoped citizenship-based taxation would be scrapped. Mr. Johnson got support from expats miffed with the American tax code and the IRS. After several Canadians filed suit to block FATCA in Canada, a named plaintiff wrote Mayor Boris offering her support. They all must feel let down that Mr. Johnson has paid the IRS bill and moved on. Lesson: the IRS wants money. The IRS collects, often because the threat of its reach is just too big. Even overseas. Even political figures. Everywhere. title: Super Bowl 49 For Dummies: From 'Inflategate' to Zebras Reviewing Half the Plays
description: Loving professional football as a fan and a former Raider writer‚Äìit was almost like covering an NFL team!‚ÄìI worry that today‚Äôs jargon, and the reverent attitude toward the league, our royal family, have made Super Bowl week incomprehensible. Of course, the game has always been such a mystery, coaches used to say, ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt know until I see the film.‚Äù Then, after they saw the film, they still wouldn‚Äôt tell us. Now, of course, they just say, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre focusing on next week,‚Äù having learned it from in-group role model Bill Belichick of the Patriots. To help understand where we are and how things got this way‚Ä¶ Inflategate‚ÄìThis season‚Äôs blockbuster: Patriots used under-inflated balls to edge Indianapolis, 45-7, galvanizing the press more than the Colts. Tweeted Indy tight end Dwayne Allen: ‚ÄúThey could have played with soap for balls and beat us.‚Äù Not that people got carried away but a Boston Globe headline, described Belichick‚Äôs ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt ask me‚Äù response as ‚ÄúBelichick throws Tom Brady under the bus.‚Äù Happily for the Patriots, Brady didn‚Äôt seem to notice having been thrown under anything. Would you buy a deflated football from this man? (Associated Press photo) The story is expected to fade into history, as did other sensational ones like Bear QB Jim McMahon mooning a news helicopter in 1985‚Äìunless the NFL declares a forfeit and sends the Colts to the Super Bowl. Why NFL won‚Äôt declare a forfeit if Belichick is caught with inflating needles‚ÄìAnd ruin this great Belichick/Brady/Patriots vs. defending champ Seattle story line? Why it couldn‚Äôt be an innocent mistake‚ÄìThe Patriots and Belichick are always pulling this crap, stealing signs, etc. Number of other NFL teams pulling this crap‚Äì29. Why These Bowls Are Super‚ÄîThat was the hot word in 1967 when they player Super Bowl I. Has been supplanted many times over, most recently by way cooler words or prefixes like ‚Äúmega,‚Äù ‚Äúiconic‚Äù and ‚Äúuber,‚Äù if decades too late to give us an annual Uber-Bowl. Media Day‚ÄîPress session on Monday of Super Bowl week. Became a mooing stampede decades ago such that in 1981 Oakland‚Äôs Jim Plunkett was asked, ‚ÄúLet me get this straight, Jim, is it blind mother, deaf father, or the other way around?‚Äù Now it‚Äôs a total geek-fest, waiting to be hijacked by media hot dogs like Mexican TV personality Ines Gomez Mont, who showed up in a wedding dress in 2008 and asked Tom Brady and Eli Manning to marry her. [embedded content] In a bigger joke, the NFL now sells tickets to the public. In a cautionary tale for our society, it sold out the entire lower deck of Phoenix University Stadium. Countdown to kickoff‚ÄîThe annual pre-game feature on TV and the stadium screen, which goes back to our nation‚Äôs founding, or the emergence of our species, and traces our history up to the start of today‚Äôs game. The Commissioner‚ÄîA god-like figure who extracts the necessary billions from networks and fans, if it means expanding the schedule to 24 games, the playoffs to 28 teams and keeping the Rams in a permanent holding pattern between Los Angeles, Anaheim and St. Louis. Answers only to the occasional independent panel, which he convenes in case of emergency to exonerate him of responsibility. Otherwise, all The Commissioner has to worry about is Keith Olbermann, who will demand that he resign if he gets the hiccups, from wherever Keith works now. If Paul Tagliabue, the NFL lawyer who lost the Raider case, could become commissioner for 17 uneventful seasons, Roger Goodell should be able to survive Olbermann, et al. Key play‚ÄîColor commentator‚Äôs term for the next play. Setting a standard that may live forever, NBC‚Äôs Al Derogatis, whom Sports Illustrated would name the best NFL commenator of all time, called the opening kickoff of Super Bowl IX a key play. Pittsburgh‚Äôs Preston Pearson returned it to his 37, but the Steelers then went three and out. With Pittsburgh ultimately beating Miami, 16-6, it didn‚Äôt turn out to mean that much. Nor would most of the plays that commenators have labeled ‚Äúkey‚Äù in the XXIX Super Bowls since.All-time great quarterback‚ÄîWhat Brady is now. Once-great quarterback‚ÄîWhat Brady was after the 41-14 loss in Kansas City Patriots‚Äô Sept. 19m, which Belichick let backup Jimmy Garropolo finish, and got questions about who would start the following week. Game manager‚ÄîQuarterback who can be trusted to throw many passes. What Seattle‚Äôs Russell Wilson is when the Seahawks lose. QB of the future‚ÄîWhat Wilson is now after running for 849 yards during the season and getting the Seahawks to their second Super Bowl in his three seasons. Misunderstood, complex personality‚ÄîBelichick, Richard Sherman and Marshawn Lynch who refuse to talk or won‚Äôt shut up, as long as they‚Äôre winning. Jerk‚ÄîBelichick, Sherman and Lynch when they‚Äôre not winning. Happily for all, it hasn‚Äôt come up that often. Yards after contact‚ÄîHip NFL metric for yardage gained after being hit. Bad tackling‚ÄîHip defensive metric for yards allowed after hitting someone.Metric‚ÄîFancy name for what were once called statistics, which in today‚Äôs augmented state are now referred as ‚Äúadvanced statistics.‚Äù‚Ä¶ Next: Uber-stats? Zebras‚ÄìRefereeing crew Under review‚ÄîVideo review. What zebras do on every other play from scrimmage. Ed Hochuli‚ÄîHighly-rated referee, known for demonstrative first-down signal that highlights his arms, bulked up from working out six hours a day. Defensive holding‚ÄîPenalty clearly spelled out in the NFL rules, capable of being read by any player, if he‚Äôs also a lawyer. An eligible receiver is considered to be an obstructing opponent ONLY to a point five yards beyond the line of scrimmage unless the player who receives the snap clearly demonstrates no further intention to pass the ball. Within this five-yard zone, a defensive player may chuck an eligible player in front of him. A defensive player is allowed to maintain continuous and unbroken contact within the five-yard zone until a point when the receiver is even with the defender. The defensive player cannot use his hands or arms to push from behind, hang onto, or encircle an eligible receiver in a manner that restricts movement as the play develops. Beyond this five-yard limitation, a defender may use his hands or arms ONLY to defend or protect himself against impending contact caused by a receiver. In such reaction, the defender may not contact a receiver who attempts to take a path to evade him. Not that this explains why Walt Coleman‚Äôs crew called more than Gene Serratore‚Äôs, Ron Torbert‚Äôs and Jeff Triplette‚Äôs combined‚Ä¶ unless Walt is a lawyer! Nope. Just looked it up. He runs a family dairy in Little Rock, Ark.. Starting the conversation‚ÄîNFL term for launching ad campaign to correct the very problem it ignored, like the poignant ‚ÄúNo More‚Äù spots after minimizing the Ray Rice incident. With the networks presumably donating the time, commercials feature football commentators like Chris Carter and Hollywood stars like Hilary Swank raise awareness so something like the Ray Rice incident can never be minimized again.

title: New Ruling: IRS Can Tax Payments To Egg Donors As Income
description: Among the many injustices life dishes out on a daily basis is the fact that many women who are actively trying to become pregnant cannot do so, while every teenager with more hormones and free time than common sense seemingly can‚Äôt keep from getting pregnant. It‚Äôs a struggle I witnessed up close and personal when my older sister tried unsuccessfully for years to conceive a child, her painful emotional battle reaching its nadir when an apathetic doctor explained to her that, ‚Äúsome women just aren‚Äôt meant to have children.‚Äù Fourteen years and three beautiful girls later, my sister got the last laugh. But the process was far from easy, which is the reality for many women. And this is precisely why the fertility industry has become a billion dollar business. There are no shortage of available alternatives for women struggling to get pregnant; unfortunately, they are typically intrusive and expensive. One option, which is the thrust of our discussion here, is ‚Äúegg donation,‚Äù whereby a female donor is supplied with hormones that increase her egg production. The eggs are then removed, fertilized in a laboratory, and ultimately implanted in the intended recipient. The term ‚Äúegg donation‚Äù is a bit of a misnomer, however, because rarely is the egg ‚Äúdonated‚Äù in the traditional, altruistic sense. Rather, the donor is typically compensated, and compensated well. This, as you might imagine, has led to a rather big tax conundrum: do the amounts received by the donor in exchange for her eggs constitute taxable income? The issue has been a huge topic of conversation on egg donor message boards (yes, there is such a thing) and in the fertility industry at large. And for good reason: because until today, there was no answer. Hours ago, however, that all changed, when the Tax Court concluded that amounts received by a donor represented taxable compensation income. What We Know About Egg Donation Donating eggs is a selective, painful, and yes, lucrative, process. While any woman can apply to be a donor, only nonsmokers between the ages of 21 and 30 who have no family history of cancer or personal history of infertility or mental disorders will even pass the initial screening. For those who are ultimately accepted, they are then subjected to a series of psychological and physical evaluations, including blood tests, pap smears, breast exams, and pregnancy tests. As they near the extraction date, donors endure a series of intrusive physical examinations and hormonal injections. The injections, which are routinely done directly into the donor‚Äôs stomach, leave burning and bruising behind. There is no disputing that the experience leaves the donor physically damaged and emotionally drained.Despite the prolonged, painful process, egg donation has been on the rise for young women for an obvious reason: it pays well. College newspapers and Craigslist are filled with offers to pay a qualifying donor as much $50,000 for her eggs; an amount that is too life-changing for many twenty-somethings to be ignored. What We Don‚Äôt Know About Egg Donation The tax consequences of dealing in the human body are largely unsettled, and they probably should be. As we‚Äôll see at the end of this discussion, any precedent that establishes that a part of the body is property, or can be sold or donated, opens up a Pandora‚Äôs Box of potential abuse. As a result, the IRS and the courts have tread lightly in establishing such precedent. In fact, over 100 years of tax law reveals little more clarity about the tax consequences of dealing in in the human body than 1) breast milk is considered property, the donation of which may result in a charitable contribution, and 2) donating blood may be either the sale of property or the performance of a service, depending on the court. It is no surprise, then, that until today, there was no precedent for how an egg donor treats the amounts received in exchange for the process for taxable income purposes. This afternoon, however, the Tax Court decided Perez v. Commissioner, 144 T.C. 4, (2015), and concluded definitively that the amounts represent taxable income. Facts in Perez Nichelle Perez, a California resident, contracted with Donor Source International, LLC (Donor Source) to sell her eggs to women who struggled to conceive on their own. During 2009, Perez went through two donation cycles and was paid a total of $20,000. For each donation, Perez entered into two contracts‚Äìone with Donor Source and one with the anonymous intended parent. The contract with Donor Source made clear that Perez was not selling her eggs, intimating instead that she was being compensated for her physical suffering: ‚ÄúDonor Fee: Donor and Intended Parents will agree upon a fee for Donor‚Äôs time, effort, inconvenience, pain, and suffering in donating her eggs. This fee is for Donor‚Äôs good faith and full compliance with the donor egg procedure, not in exchange for or purchase of eggs and the quantity or quality of eggs retrieved will not affect the Donor Fee. The parties plainly acknowledge and agree that the funds provided to the Donor shall not in any way constitute payment to Donor for her eggs.‚ÄùThe contract with the prospective parent read the same, stating that payment was ‚Äúin consideration for all of her pain, suffering, time, inconvenience, and efforts.‚Äù Taxpayer Position The underlined contractual language above was of critical importance to Perez. This is because generally, Section 61 of the Internal Revenue Code provides that gross income includes all income from whatever sources derived, including compensation for services. There is an exception found at Section 104(a)(2), however, which excludes from taxable income the amount of any damages (other than punitive damages) received on account of personal injuries or physical sickness. Based on the language of the contract, Perez believed that the $20,000 she received in 2009 was to compensate her for the physical injuries she suffered as part of the egg donation process, and thus, fit within the ambit of Section 104 and was excludable from her taxable income. A cursory search of the internet reveals that many donors feel exactly the same way. As a result, Perez did not report the $20,000 of taxable income, despite the fact that Donor Source issued her a Form 1099 in that amount. IRS Position The IRS disagreed, arguing that regardless of the contractual language, the $20,000 Perez received was in exchange for services provided; in essence, while Perez may not have been selling her eggs, she was providing a service when she went through the process of donating her eggs. Tax Court Decision With some trepidation, the Tax Court took on the issue of whether the $20,000 Perez received was in fact taxable compensation, or if it represented a tax-free recovery of physical damages. It is important to note, however, that just as important to Judge Holmes was what the case wasn‚Äôt about: it wasn‚Äôt about whether human eggs are capital assets, how to allocate basis in the human body, the holding period for body parts, or the character of gain from the sale of those parts, which from a tax geek‚Äôs perspective is a damn shame, because that would have made for fascinating theater. The court didn‚Äôt have to take on these issues, however, because the contracts made clear that Perez was not selling her eggs, as she would be compensated whether she produced any useable eggs or not. To determine if the payments were a tax-free recovery of physical damages, the court looked next to the language of the Section 104 regulations; specifically, were the amounts received by Perez ‚Äùdamages‚Äù under the meaning of the regulations? Reg. Section 1.104-1(c)(1) defines the term ‚Äúdamages‚Äù as ‚Äúan amount received (other than workers‚Äô compensation‚Äù through prosecution of a legal suit or action, or through a settlement agreement entered into in lieu of prosecution.‚Äù Because Perez conceded she had neither sued nor settled with Donor Source, she attacked the very validity of the regulations, arguing that the IRS did not have the power to limit ‚Äúdamages‚Äù to amounts received in a lawsuit or due to the threat of one. Instead, ‚Äúdamages‚Äù should extend to situations where a taxpayer received compensation in money for a loss regardless of legal suit or action. I‚Äôll spare you the details of the court‚Äôs jaunt through the legislative history, but ultimately, Judge Holmes concluded that the regulations were in fact valid. And as a result, they failed to help Perez, because she did not receive the $20,000 as a result of a legal suit or action. More importantly, she did not receive the amounts from any type of action ‚Äî legal or otherwise‚Äì taken after the physical injuries occurred; to the contrary, she entered into a contract with Donor Source providing for $20,000 of payment before the injuries took place. Even more damning, the injuries were both anticipated and consensual; in fact, they were of the exact nature that Perez was advised to expect when she entered into her contract. Thus, Judge Holmes concluded: The injury here , as painful as it was to Perez, was exactly within the scope of the medical procedures to which she contractually consented. Twice. Had Donor Source or the clinic exceeded the scope of Perez‚Äôs consent, Perez may have a claim for damages. Her physical pain was a byproduct of performing a service contract, and we find that the payments were not made to compensate her for some unwanted invasion against her bodily integrity but to compensate her for services rendered. As a result, the amounts paid to Perez, and presumably to all future egg donors, represented taxable income.Difficult a decision as it was, it was likely necessary to avoid the dangerous precedent mentioned at the outset of this column. If an egg donor could successfully argue that amounts received compensated her for injuries of a job she consented to and were thus tax-free, than what is to prevent a football player from arguing that part of his salary is intended to compensate him for concussions suffered, or a miner from contending that a portion of his compensation was meant to make him whole for future lung damage, resulting in a portion of the compensation in both cases becoming tax-free? The tax law is harsh and unforgiving, and often times, precedent must be decided with an eye towards the future, and with consideration of the inevitable abuse of the authority established by enterprising taxpayers. Thus, while the decision in Perez is sure to be unpopular, it was the correct one. follow along on twitter @nittigrittytax

title: Hedge Fund Chief: 'Sorry' For Losing It All
description: It‚Äôs one of those rare moments of humility on Wall Street, a placed where ‚Äúindicted but never convicted‚Äù is a badge of honor. A hedge fund chief who lost all of his client‚Äôs money told them he was sorry. Owen Li, founder of Canarsie Capital, wrote to his clients to say he had run their accounts down from $100 million less than a year ago to just $200,000. Reportedly, he got into a hole and took on a string of high-risk bests to try to save his firm. It didn‚Äôt work out. ‚ÄùMy only hope is that you understand that I acted in an attempt ‚Äî however misguided ‚Äî to generate higher returns for the fund and its investors. But even so, I acted overzealously, causing you devastating losses for which there is no excuse,‚Äù he wrote. Here‚Äôs the thing, though. Hedge funds are not supposed to be running extremely high-risk strategies. They‚Äôre supposed to ‚Äúhedge‚Äù risk by investing in ways that protect wealthy investors from dramatic losses. You might not get an amazing return from a hedge fund (and it‚Äôs interesting that people think that‚Äôs the goal) but instead get a reasonable return with minimal risk of big losses. That‚Äôs why rich people use them. A hedge fund, if correctly operated, is in fact just one slice of a larger asset pie, one which includes stocks, bonds, real estate and commodities. There has been a lot of research over decades to support the idea that again, properly run, a limited hedge fund allocation can lower overall volatility in a very large portfolio. That‚Äôs why universities and endowments use them. Of course, as with any hot investing trend, demand outstrips supply. CalPERS, the big California state pension fund, famously gave up on hedge funds in 2013, precisely because their high fees were unjustifiable in the face of shoddy performance. Hedge fund alternative For ordinary retirement investors, the risk is far, far too high and the hedge effect can be purchased much more cheaply in other ways. By simply owning a well-designed, well-allocated portfolio of index funds you get a lot of risk management at a very low price. Rebalancing with discipline allows you to book gains as they occur, selling high and buying low in a timely fashion. All that‚Äôs left is to make sure that your exposure to higher volatility asset classes ‚Äî chiefly stocks ‚Äî is slowly lowered over time as you near retirement. Sometimes, you don‚Äôt get what you pay for in an actively managed fund, and sometimes you get something you never bargained for ‚Äî high risk and poor oversight from the managers themselves.
